content.webTitle: Uxbridge on Boris Johnson: 'No one has seen him here in years'

fields.headline: Uxbridge on Boris Johnson: 'No one has seen him here in years'
fields.bodyText: Deep in Metroland, even the handful of critics to be found in Boris Johnson’s constituency doubt his late-night row with his partner, Carrie Symonds, will knock him off course towards No 10. Enjoying a lunchtime break from her job in a recruitment agency, Cherry Holliday, 26, stressed she was “not guilty” of helping make Johnson the MP for Uxbridge and South Ruislip in west London. “I only moved here a year ago so don’t blame me for getting him back into parliament,” she said. Asked about the loud argument, which was reported to police after neighbours heard screaming and crashing in Symonds’ flat, Holliday added: “I don’t want him to lead this country but do I really think that that argument will stop him? If I’m honest, I don’t think so. “It’s not us the voters who are electing him, it’s his fan club who will make him prime minister and I don’t think at this stage anything he does will change their minds.” Her colleague Aalia Rehmanji, 23, said the incident should have stopped Johnson in his tracks but, like Holliday, she believed it would not. “Maybe, just maybe, the women in the Tory party who are electing the new leader will think twice about opting for Boris Johnson but, like Cherry, I guess it won’t matter,” said Rehmanji. John Hooker, drinking a pint outside The Three Tuns, a pub close to Uxbridge underground station, said he was proudly pro-Brexit and had lived in the Tory-dominated constituency all his life. But Hooker, 64, described Johnson as a “silly sod” for refusing to make any comment about the incident with Symonds in the early hours of Friday. “All he has to do is put up his hand and say, ‘Yes, me and the good lady had a row. It’s nobody’s business but ours and it’s over.’ Once he does that then everyone will move on and forget about it. My only problem with Boris is no one has seen him around here in years.” While Hooker is a robust Brexiter, another member of his “Monday club” drinks circle Liam McNamara said he voted remain. Yet despite opposing Johnson’s policy of crashing out of Europe if, under his premiership, the UK cannot secure an EU exit deal, McNamara believed the row would have little impact on the Tory leadership contest. “I wouldn’t vote for him but it’s not going to make a blind bit of difference what happened between him and his girlfriend. That’s how most people will see this,” said McNamara. Elsewhere in the heart of the constituency, Lorraine Kimber’s elderly German friend Helen Lipskombe raised no objections when she described her hero Johnson as a “young Churchill”. As they sipped their coffees, Lipskombe, 90, nodded her approval and interrupted Kimber’s gushing over the wannabe prime minister to say, “Yes, I love Boris too!” Lipskombe moved from Kiel in Germany to England in 1948 and until March this year worked behind the bar of the local Conservative club for 30 years. “I only met Boris once in the club during an election campaign but he was very nice, lovely manners, polite to everyone,” she said. Kimber was outraged on Johnson’s behalf. “They are out to get Boris,” she thundered. “They are trying to do him down because they are desperate to stop him. He’s too intelligent for his opponent so they will resort to anything. Bless poor Boris, he doesn’t deserve this, nobody does. I still have faith in him, faith that he will take us out of Europe where we will be far better off. He really does remind me of a young Churchill.”
